Type.Name: Double

TypeSignature.Value: .class public sequential sealed serializable Double extends System.ValueType implements System.IComparable, System.IFormattable
public struct Double : IComparable, IComparable<double>, IConvertible, IEquatable<double>, IFormattable

Type.ThreadingSafetyStatement: This type is safe for multithreaded operations.

summary.para: Represents a 64-bit double-precision floating-point number.

remarks.para: is a 64-bit double precision floating-point type that represents values ranging from approximately 5.0E-324 to 1.7E+308 and from approximately -5.0E-324 to -1.7E+308 with a precision of 15-16 decimal digits. The type conforms to standard IEC 60559:1989, Binary Floating-point Arithmetic for Microprocessor Systems.
A can represent the following values:

item.term: The finite set of non-zero values of the form * 2e, where is 1 or -1, and 0 < < 253 and -1075 <= <= 970.

Positive infinity and negative infinity. Infinities are produced by operations that produce results with a magnitude greater than that which can be represented by a , such as dividing a non-zero number by zero. For example, using operands, 1.0 / 0.0 yields positive infinity, and -1.0 / 0.0 yields negative infinity. Operations include passing parameters and returning values.
The value (NaN). NaN values are produced by invalid floating-point operations, such as dividing zero by zero.

remarks.para: When performing binary operations, if one of the operands is a , then the other operand is required to be an integral type or a floating-point type ( or ). Prior to performing the operation, if the other operand is not a , it is converted to , and the operation is performed using at least range and precision. If the operation produces a numeric result, the type of the result is .

The floating-point operators, including the assignment operators, do not throw exceptions. Instead, in exceptional situations, the result of a floating-point operation is zero, infinity, or NaN, as described below:

item.term: If the result of a floating-point operation is too small for the destination format, the result of the operation is zero.

If the magnitude of the result of a floating-point operation is too large for the destination format, the result of the operation is positive infinity or negative infinity, as appropriate for the sign of the result.
If a floating-point operation is invalid, the result of the operation is NaN.
If one or both operands of a floating-point operation are NaN, the result of the operation is NaN.

remarks.para: Conforming implementations of the CLI are permitted to perform floating-point operations using a precision that is higher than that required by the type. For example, hardware architectures that support an "extended" or "long double" floating-point type with greater range and precision than the type could implicitly perform all floating-point operations using this higher precision type. Expressions evaluated using a higher precision might cause a finite result to be produced instead of an infinity.

summary.para: Returns the sort order of the current instance compared to the specified .

returns.para: The return value is a negative number, zero, or a positive number reflecting the sort order of the current instance as compared to . For non-zero return values, the exact value returned by this method is unspecified. The following table defines the return value:

description.para: Current instance is a NaN and is not a NaN.
Current instance and are both NaN, positive infinity, or negative infinity.
Current instance is not a NaN and is a NaN.

para.block: This method is implemented to support the interface.

summary.para: Returns the sort order of the current instance compared to the specified .

returns.para: The return value is a negative number, zero, or a positive number reflecting the sort order of the current instance as compared to . For non-zero return values, the exact value returned by this method is unspecified. The following table defines the return value:

description.para: Current instance is a NaN and is not a NaN and is not a null reference.
Current instance and are both NaN, positive infinity, or negative infinity.
Current instance is not a NaN and is a NaN.

block.para: This method is implemented to support the interface. Note that, although a NaN is not considered to be equal to another NaN (even itself), the interface requires that A. (A) return zero.

summary.para: Represents the smallest positive value greater than zero.

remarks.para: The value of this constant is 4.9406564584124654E-324.

summary.para: Determines whether the current instance and the specified represent the same value.

returns.para: if has the same value as the current instance, otherwise . If either or the current instance is a NaN and the other is not, returns . If and the current instance are both NaN, positive infinity, or negative infinity, returns .

para.block: This method is implemented to support the interface.

returns.para: if is a with the same value as the current instance, otherwise . If is a null reference or is not an instance of , returns . If either or the current instance is a NaN and the other is not, returns . If and the current instance are both NaN, positive infinity, or negative infinity, returns .

returns.para: A containing the hash code for this instance.

remarks.para: The algorithm used to generate the hash code is unspecified.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig static bool IsInfinity(float64 d)

summary.para: Determines whether the specified represents an infinity, which can be either positive or negative.

returns.para: if represents a positive or negative infinity value; otherwise .

para.block: Floating-point operations return positive or negative infinity values to signal an overflow condition.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig static bool IsNaN(float64 d)

summary.para: Determines whether the value of the specified is undefined (Not-a-Number).

returns.para: if represents a NaN value; otherwise

para.block: Floating-point operations return NaN values to signal that the result of the operation is undefined. For example, dividing (Double) 0.0 by 0.0 results in a NaN value.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig static bool IsNegativeInfinity(float64 d)

summary.para: Determines whether the specified represents a negative infinity value.

returns.para: if represents a negative infinity value; otherwise .

para.block: Floating-point operations return negative infinity values to signal an overflow condition.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig static bool IsPositiveInfinity(float64 d)

summary.para: Determines whether the specified represents a positive infinity value.

returns.para: if represents a positive infinity value; otherwise .

para.block: Floating-point operations return positive infinity values to signal an overflow condition.

summary.para: Contains the maximum positive value for the type.

remarks.para: The value of this constant is 1.7976931348623157E+308.

summary.para: Contains the minimum (most negative) value for the type.

remarks.para: The value of this constant is -1.7976931348623157E+308.

summary.para:
Represents an undefined result of operations involving
.

remarks.para: Not-a-Number (NaN) values are returned when the result of a operation is undefined.
A NaN value is not equal to any other value, including another NaN value.
The value of this field is obtained by dividing zero by zero.

para.block: represents one of many possible NaN values. To test whether a value is a NaN, use the method.

summary.para: Represents a negative infinity of type .

remarks.para: The value of this constant is obtained by dividing a negative by zero.

para.block: To test whether a value is a negative infinity value, use the method.

summary.para: Represents a positive infinity of type .

para.block: To test whether a value is a positive infinity value, use the method.

summary.para: Returns a representation of the value of the current instance.

returns.para: A representation of the current instance formatted using the general format specifier, ("G"). The string takes into account the current system culture.

remarks.para: This version of is equivalent to (, ).

block.para: The general format specifier formats the number in either fixed-point or exponential notation form. For a detailed description of the general format, see the interface.
